values.title: typo in wiki system setup instructions

content.raw:
Right at the end, it tells you to run:

    roslaunch ihmc_valkyrie_ros valkyrie_warmup_graddle_cache.launch

But "gradle" is spelled wrong. It should be:

    roslaunch ihmc_valkyrie_ros valkyrie_warmup_gradle_cache.launch
content.html:
Right at the end, it tells you to run:

roslaunch ihmc_valkyrie_ros valkyrie_warmup_graddle_cache.launch

But "gradle" is spelled wrong. It should be:

roslaunch ihmc_valkyrie_ros valkyrie_warmup_gradle_cache.launch

content.raw:
When running the qual1 or qual2 launch files they fail because the subdirectory '$HOME/valkyrie' is not previously created. Creating the directory allows the process to continue. 

The directions for setting up srcsim should mention the need for this directory and its creation.
content.html:
When running the qual1 or qual2 launch files they fail because the subdirectory '$HOME/valkyrie' is not previously created. Creating the directory allows the process to continue.

The directions for setting up srcsim should mention the need for this directory and its creation.

The controller manager crashes as it tries to initialize the hardware interface.  This continues after updating with the fix for the $HOME/valkyrie directory missing issue (issue #4).  See the log below.

I am wondering if it is a race condition.  It will load when gazebo_gui seg faults (that happens about 20% of the time).  Log of that follows the controller manager crash log.

content.raw: Hello, Im a bit confused about the name of the robot. Based on the wiki and the images on the wiki, the robot is referred to as R5, but I have always seen the robot called Valkyrie in various articles and around the internet? Is this the Valkyrie robot or is it a different robot? Or does the R5 software also run the Valkyrie robot so both names are found in the documentation?

Is this the Valkyrie robot or is it a different robot? Or does the R5 software also run the Valkyrie robot so both names are found in the documentation?

content.raw:
The following problems were encountered when following the setup instructions on a clean install of Ubuntu 14.04.5. This was tested on both a VM and a real machine, both having an Intel Core i7 and 12G of memory. Both had the same errors. These were tested after the correction for the missing valkyrie directory issue was resolved.

1. The directory  $HOME/.gazebo/models is required for step 11 to complete and it does not exist. I created the directory and it continued without error. Is there a missing step that should have created this directory?

2. The line:
   source /opt/nasa/indigo/setup.bash
should have been run before step 12 in order to setup the environment. Should this line have been added to the default startup bash script?

3. The rosrun command is missing from the default install and creates an error in the "test your installation" script. I installed this with:
   sudo apt-get install ros-indigo-rosbash
and it passed the error.
content.html:
The following problems were encountered when following the setup instructions on a clean install of Ubuntu 14.04.5. This was tested on both a VM and a real machine, both having an Intel Core i7 and 12G of memory. Both had the same errors. These were tested after the correction for the missing valkyrie directory issue was resolved.

  1. The directory $HOME/.gazebo/models is required for step 11 to complete and it does not exist. I created the directory and it continued without error. Is there a missing step that should have created this directory?

  2. The line: source /opt/nasa/indigo/setup.bash should have been run before step 12 in order to setup the environment. Should this line have been added to the default startup bash script?

  3. The rosrun command is missing from the default install and creates an error in the "test your installation" script. I installed this with: sudo apt-get install ros-indigo-rosbash and it passed the error.

content.raw: This is a note that the srcsim deb is currently only built for amd64 on Ubuntu, and is not available for i386. The wiki will be updated accordingly.
content.html: This is a note that the srcsim deb is currently only built for amd64 on Ubuntu, and is not available for i386. The wiki will be updated accordingly.

content.raw:
~~~
Ubuntu version: 14.04.5 LTS
Gazebo version: 7.4.0
ROS version: Indigo
~~~

There are a number of missing topics after running the command:
`$ roslaunch srcsim qual1.launch init:="true"`
Then in a new terminal type:
`$ rostopic list`
You can see that for /multisense/ related topics there lists only:

~~~
/multisense/camera/left/camera_info
/multisense/camera/left/image_raw
/multisense/camera/left/parameter_descriptions
/multisense/camera/left/parameter_updates
/multisense/camera/right/camera_info
/multisense/camera/right/image_raw
/multisense/camera/right/parameter_descriptions
/multisense/camera/right/parameter_updates
/multisense/fps
/multisense/imu
/multisense/joint_states
/multisense/lidar_scan
/multisense/set_fps
/multisense/set_spindle_speed
~~~

While on multisense Sl's [website](http://docs.carnegierobotics.com/SL/api.html#api) definitely lists more topics. As a result of what I can only access, I can't perform any point cloud or other necessary perceptions without writing libraries from scratch. Is there a way to fix this? Maybe it's related to the warnings at launch?

values.title: qual1 answer log entries not correct?  also, qual1 scoring formula.

content.raw:
I am able to generate the switch and answer entries in the qual1 log file, but I am unclear on what the switch line is showing.
The index states that the entries are

```
#!python

switch <light_index> <r> <g> <b> <a> <sim_sec> <sim_nsec>
answer <x> <y> <z> <r> <g> <b> <sim_sec> <sim_nsec>
```
but the entries for the "switch" rows do not look correct.  For example, here is the output when a green light was displayed.  The RGB values shown in the switch entry are 0, 0, 0, instead of the correct answer which was 0, 255, 0.

```
#!python
answer 414 332 0 0 255 0 103 95000000
switch 30 0 0 0 1 103 96000000
```
Also, what does the entry <a> supposed to represent?  How do we translate from switch number, e.g., "30" to an x, y, z location in space so that we can create a score?  Do we have to back that out from the URDF?

Finally, what is the formula for the score from these data?
content.html:

answer <x> <y> <z> <r> <g> <b> <sim_sec> <sim_nsec>

answer 414 332 0 0 255 0 103 95000000
switch 30 0 0 0 1 103 96000000

Also, what does the entry <a> supposed to represent? How do we translate from switch number, e.g., "30" to an x, y, z location in space so that we can create a score? Do we have to back that out from the URDF?

Finally, what is the formula for the score from these data?

values.title: IHMC Java real time permission problems

content.raw:
Hello,
Hello I have an Ubuntu 14.04 LTS (64-bit) system. 

I initially installed ROS Indigo on my own.  And followed the instructions in 
#!/osrf/srcsim/wiki/system_setup

Everything seems to compile and the java libraries are also successfully built.

After sourcing /opt/nasa, I launch:
roslaunch srcsim qual2.launch init:=true walk_test:=true

I see valkyrie and task#2, but the controller is not initiated.
I am getting the following errors regarding realtime threads with Java:

[ERROR] [1479218526.837678586, 6.291000000]: java.lang.RuntimeException: Cannot start realtime thread, do you have permission
[ERROR] [1479218526.837843116, 6.291000000]: 	at us.ihmc.realtime.RealtimeThread.start(RealtimeThread.java:112)
[ERROR] [1479218526.837938407, 6.291000000]: 	at us.ihmc.util.PeriodicRealtimeThreadScheduler.schedule(PeriodicRealtimeThreadScheduler.java:35)
[ERROR] [1479218526.838034960, 6.291000000]: 	at us.ihmc.commonWalkingControlModules.controllerAPI.input.ControllerNetworkSubscriber.<init>(ControllerNetworkSubscriber.java:71)
[ERROR] [1479218526.838143691, 6.291000000]: 	at us.ihmc.commonWalkingControlModules.highLevelHumanoidControl.factories.MomentumBasedControllerFactory.createControllerNetworkSubscriber(MomentumBasedControllerFactory.java:141)
[ERROR] [1479218526.838264199, 6.291000000]: 	at us.ihmc.valkyrieRosControl.ValkyrieRosControlController.createDRCControllerFactory(ValkyrieRosControlController.java:140)
[ERROR] [1479218526.838378413, 6.291000000]: 	at us.ihmc.valkyrieRosControl.ValkyrieRosControlController.init(ValkyrieRosControlController.java:253)
[ERROR] [1479218526.838493800, 6.291000000]: 	at us.ihmc.rosControl.IHMCRosControlJavaBridge.initFromNative(IHMCRosControlJavaBridge.java:103)
[ERROR] [1479218526.838645496, 6.291000000]: Initializing controller 'ihmc_valkyrie_control_java_bridge' failed

Since the controller fails to load, Valkyrie falls down when released from the harness. There are other issues that also appear after this first error.

Is this an installation issue or is this a permission issue? I checked 
/opt/ros/indigo/share/ihmc_ros_java_adapter is owned by the user ( using ls -l )

Any ideas? The java libraries are binaries so this is difficult to debug for me.

content.raw:
The tutorial for qual 1 states:

"Send the location, in meters relative to the head frame of R3, and color, using a range of (0,1) for each RGB component, of each LED to the ```/srcsim/qual1/``` light topic"

Everything is clear except for the fact that I'm unsure what constitutes the head frame. Since the multisense unit is mounted upside down in Valkyrie's head. Do we have to invert the coordinate system? Or do we just leave the coordinates as is? It gets a little more confusing too because the left eye will then become the right eye and so on. A little clarification will help.
content.html:
The tutorial for qual 1 states:

"Send the location, in meters relative to the head frame of R3, and color, using a range of (0,1) for each RGB component, of each LED to the /srcsim/qual1/ light topic"

Everything is clear except for the fact that I'm unsure what constitutes the head frame. Since the multisense unit is mounted upside down in Valkyrie's head. A little clarification will help.

content.raw:
When I run the command: 
```
#!
gazebo -p ~/.gazebo/log/<timestamp>/gzserver/state.log
```
I get the error:
```
#!
[FATAL] [1479541568.200997765]: A ROS node for Gazebo has not been initialized, unable to load plugin. 
Load the Gazebo system plugin 'libgazebo_ros_api_plugin.so' in the gazebo_ros package)
```

I'm unsure how to fix this issue. I only have this error when I attempt to play back valkyrie ie. (qual1, qual2) logs. If I simply just log in gazebo of a random object I don't receive this issue. But otherwise I can't review my srcsim log files.

Fix: So apparently to run your log files, you run the command: 

```
#!

roscore
```
Then in a new terminal run the command:

```
#!
rosrun gazebo_ros gazebo -p ~/.gazebo/log/<timestamp>/gzserver/state.log

```
This will play back your log files without the error. Suggestion to update wiki. 
I also encountered an error after playing your log file. For some reason the gzserver client doesn't close after quitting the gui. So I had to manually do it through system monitor.

content.raw:
It is possible to get a score for qual1?  I think that I am reporting all of the locations accurately in XYZRBG and have done local tests such as viewing them in the correct frame, along with the point cloud, in rviz.  Nevertheless, it seems easy to have some detail be wrong that causes the whole thing to be messed up in the actual scoring.  

Is there some way to obtain a score for a data set to be sure that it is all working correctly?  For example, can we submit the data and get back an official score?

Also, it is still unclear what the scoring method is going to be.  For example, is it least mean squared error of all 6 parameters?  Finally, what is the acceptable range for the error to pass qual1?
content.html:
It is possible to get a score for qual1? I think that I am reporting all of the locations accurately in XYZRBG and have done local tests such as viewing them in the correct frame, along with the point cloud, in rviz. Nevertheless, it seems easy to have some detail be wrong that causes the whole thing to be messed up in the actual scoring.

Is there some way to obtain a score for a data set to be sure that it is all working correctly? For example, can we submit the data and get back an official score?

Also, it is still unclear what the scoring method is going to be. For example, is it least mean squared error of all 6 parameters? Finally, what is the acceptable range for the error to pass qual1?

values.title: gazebo head frame or ROS head frame?

content.raw:
Since the camera is mounted upside down, we receive inverted images.  The standard tf transform from camera to head frame in ROS does not take that into account.  It makes sense that we should report values that refer to the head frame in Gazebo.  In that case we need to invert the transform from ROS.

For the XYZ coordinates in qual1, should we submit the values for the Gazebo head frame or for the ROS head frame?
content.html:
Since the camera is mounted upside down, we receive inverted images. The standard tf transform from camera to head frame in ROS does not take that into account. It makes sense that we should report values that refer to the head frame in Gazebo. In that case we need to invert the transform from ROS.

For the XYZ coordinates in qual1, should we submit the values for the Gazebo head frame or for the ROS head frame?

content.raw:
The following command returns the results shown:


```
#!c++

rostopic echo -c --noarr /multisense/lidar_scan

header: 
seq: 17230
stamp: 
secs: 451
nsecs: 831000000
frame_id: head_hokuyo_frame
angle_min: -2.3561899662
angle_max: 2.3561899662
angle_increment: 0.00436331471428
time_increment: 0.0
scan_time: 0.0
range_min: 0.10000000149
range_max: 30.0
---
```
The time_increment field is always 0.0. The lidar is spinning in Gazebo. 

I believe this causes the lidar output to always appear in a horizontal plane after processing with laser_assembler instead of the expected 3d image. Without the time_increment the incline of the lidar can not be calculated using the angle_increment.

A caveat is I changed the valkyrie_sim_gazebo_sync.urdf file to use "ray" and not "gpu_ray" since while my system has an Intel GPU it's not being used for some reason. 

```
#!base

Ubuntu 14.04 LTS
```

The time_increment field is always 0.0. The lidar is spinning in Gazebo.

I believe this causes the lidar output to always appear in a horizontal plane after processing with laser_assembler instead of the expected 3d image. Without the time_increment the incline of the lidar can not be calculated using the angle_increment.

A caveat is I changed the valkyrie_sim_gazebo_sync.urdf file to use "ray" and not "gpu_ray" since while my system has an Intel GPU it's not being used for some reason. 

Ubuntu 14.04 LTS

content.raw: For ROSJava to work properly, it needs ROS_IP to be set specifically to 127.0.0.1 when running nodes locally. A step should be added to the setup tutorials that has the user add an export line to their .bashrc. I've attached a version of the system_setup.md with the necessary changes to this issue.
content.html: For ROSJava to work properly, it needs ROS_IP to be set specifically to 127.0.0.1 when running nodes locally. A step should be added to the setup tutorials that has the user add an export line to their .bashrc. I've attached a version of the system_setup.md with the necessary changes to this issue.

content.raw:
I am not sure if this is the intended behavior, but I was using the topic /ihmc_ros/valkyrie/output/footstep_status for debugging, but the following holds:

Whenever msg.Status == STARTED, then always msg.RobotSide == LEFT.
What I get from this is that this topic cannot tell us which foot started moving. 

From the message documentation, the following should hold:
uint8 STARTED=0 # execution of a footstep has begun. actualFootPositionInWorld and actualFootOrientationInWorld should be ignored in this state

However, it doesn't say that msg.RobotSide should also be disregarded when msg.Status == STARTED. Is this a bug, or should I just assume that this topic won't be telling us which foot started moving?
content.html:
I am not sure if this is the intended behavior, but I was using the topic /ihmc_ros/valkyrie/output/footstep_status for debugging, but the following holds:

Whenever msg.Status == STARTED, then always msg.RobotSide == LEFT. What I get from this is that this topic cannot tell us which foot started moving.

From the message documentation, the following should hold: uint8 STARTED=0 # execution of a footstep has begun. actualFootPositionInWorld and actualFootOrientationInWorld should be ignored in this state

However, it doesn't say that msg.RobotSide should also be disregarded when msg.Status == STARTED. Is this a bug, or should I just assume that this topic won't be telling us which foot started moving?

values.title: Issues attempting to replay Gazebo log file

content.raw:
I am attempting to replay my log file for task 1 using the command described on the qual1 page:
```
gazebo -p ~/.gazebo/log/<timestamp>/gzserver/state.log
```

But I get the error
```
[FATAL] A ROS node for Gazebo has not been initialized, unable to load plugin. Load the Gazebo system plugin 'libgazebo_ros_api_plugin.so' in the gazebo_ros package)
```

I believe the command should be changed to read
```
rosrun gazebo_ros gazebo -p ~/.gazebo/log/<timestamp>/gzserver/state.log
```
while also having `roscore` running in another terminal.


However, this still does not allow me be play back my log file. When running the `gazebo_ros` command I listed above, I get the following terminal output:
```
[ INFO] Finished loading Gazebo ROS API Plugin.
[ INFO] waitForService: Service [/gazebo/set_physics_properties] has not been advertised, waiting...
[ INFO] waitForService: Service [/gazebo/set_physics_properties] is now available.
[ INFO] Physics dynamic reconfigure ready.
[ INFO] Camera Plugin (robotNamespace = /), Info: Using the 'robotNamespace' param: '/'
[ INFO] Camera Plugin (robotNamespace = /), Info: Using the 'robotNamespace' param: '/'
[ INFO] Camera Plugin (ns = /)  <tf_prefix_>, set to ""
[ INFO] Camera Plugin (ns = /)  <tf_prefix_>, set to ""
[ INFO] Laser Plugin (robotNamespace = /), Info: Using the 'robotNamespace' param: '/'
[ INFO] Starting GazeboRosLaser Plugin (ns = /)!
[ INFO] GPU Laser Plugin (ns = /) <tf_prefix_>, set to ""
[ INFO] LoadThread function completed
```
The Gazebo splash screen opens up, along with a Gazebo window to a black, empty world. I suspect that since my logfile is around 65MB, it is simply taking a long time to load. But after 1 hour, the program is in the same state (gzserver and gzclient are both using upwards of 90% memory throughout this time). So I am wondering if there is something else I need to be running in the background to play back the log file.

values.title: Collapse on Startup - Began after a system software update

content.raw:
This may be related to other startup issues but it just started for me after I upgraded the software on the overall system. Previously the system was working fine. 

```
#!text
Ubuntu 14.04.05
i7 4 core
```
To address this I used Synaptic to do a complete removal of ROS, Gazebo and srcsim. Installed using Synaptic and the directions on the setup page. I still get collapses. 

I noted that the changes to add the stereo processing package were not in the qual1 or qual2 launch files. I added them in. Are they supposed to be loaded with the latest packages?

I'll attach the console log and other log files for a 'clean' startup. I say 'clean'. because I'm seeing more problems - strange errors about processing - with the startup than I did previously.
content.html:
This may be related to other startup issues but it just started for me after I upgraded the software on the overall system. Previously the system was working fine. 

Ubuntu 14.04.05
i7 4 core

To address this I used Synaptic to do a complete removal of ROS, Gazebo and srcsim. Installed using Synaptic and the directions on the setup page. I still get collapses.

I noted that the changes to add the stereo processing package were not in the qual1 or qual2 launch files. I added them in. Are they supposed to be loaded with the latest packages?

I'll attach the console log and other log files for a 'clean' startup. I say 'clean'. because I'm seeing more problems - strange errors about processing - with the startup than I did previously.

content.raw: The system setup [tutorial](#!/osrf/srcsim/wiki/system_setup) has instructions on using the debian package. How about building this package from source?

content.raw:
Many of the IMMC topics are opaque as to their use or meaning. A few are listed below. From the topic names and the associated messages it is impossible to know what they mean. Note, this is not asking about the messages but why the topic is made available and its purpose.

Additionally, some are clear as to purpose but there is not explanation of what can be expected in the content of the message. Most of these are irrelevant to the qualifying task but may gain in importance for the actual competition.


```
#!text

/ihmc_ros/valkyrie/output/robot_motion_status : std_msgs/String (content?)
/ihmc_ros/valkyrie/output/behavior : std_msgs/Int32
/ihmc_ros/valkyrie/output/capturability/capture_point : ihmc_msgs/Point2dRosMessage
/ihmc_ros/valkyrie/output/capturability/center_of_mass : geometry_msgs/Point32
/ihmc_ros/valkyrie/output/capturability/desired_capture_point : ihmc_msgs/Point2dRosMessage

```

values.title: will the fastest task2 simulation log win?

content.raw:
As the walking near the highest speed, the robot has a greater tendency to fail over.

It appears the highest score for tasks two goes to the fastest completion time without falling over. Since team aren't required to submit their code for the qualifying round, I assume this is the case.

Is this a correct interpretation of the rules?
content.html:

It appears the highest score for tasks two goes to the fastest completion time without falling over. Since team aren't required to submit their code for the qualifying round, I assume this is the case.

Is this a correct interpretation of the rules?

content.raw:
The HandDesiredConfigurationRosMessage appears not to work. Let me know if anyone else has gotten it to work.

This message should cause the hand to change configuration but doesn't. Checking the data with rostopic shows the data is valid. 

```
#!text

rostopic pub -1 /ihmc_ros/valkyrie/control/hand_desired_configuration ihmc_msgs/HandDesiredConfigurationRosMessage '1' '2' '1'

```
content.html:
The HandDesiredConfigurationRosMessage appears not to work. Let me know if anyone else has gotten it to work.

This message should cause the hand to change configuration but doesn't. Checking the data with rostopic shows the data is valid. 

rostopic pub -1 /ihmc_ros/valkyrie/control/hand_desired_configuration ihmc_msgs/HandDesiredConfigurationRosMessage '1' '2' '1'

content.raw:
I have spent a bit of time testing the robot's arms using both the files arm_traj_yaml.py/Traj_data.yaml and the file armDemo.py.  While the shoulder joints, upper arms and elbow joints work quite well, the lower arms and wrists don't work at all.  I haven't tested them, but I'm told the hands don't work either.  I also tested the neck using the files neck_traj_yaml.py/Traj_data.yaml and it still doesn't work.  While it may be possible to complete the Qual2 trail by bludgeoning  the door switch with the dead stumps, if the switch worked, it won't be possible to continue the challenge to the more advanced level with the arms in their current state.

The machine is a quad core I7 with 16 gigs of RAM.
content.html:
I have spent a bit of time testing the robot's arms using both the files arm_traj_yaml.py/Traj_data.yaml and the file armDemo.py. While the shoulder joints, upper arms and elbow joints work quite well, the lower arms and wrists don't work at all. I haven't tested them, but I'm told the hands don't work either. I also tested the neck using the files neck_traj_yaml.py/Traj_data.yaml and it still doesn't work. While it may be possible to complete the Qual2 trail by bludgeoning the door switch with the dead stumps, if the switch worked, it won't be possible to continue the challenge to the more advanced level with the arms in their current state.

The machine is a quad core I7 with 16 gigs of RAM.

content.raw:
I want to automate the launching and store the logs in a database.
Are teams allowed to change the defaults in the launch file?

ie.
  <arg name="extra_gazebo_args" default=""/>
  <arg name="init" default="false" />  
to
 <arg name="extra_gazebo_args" default="-r"/>
  <arg name="init" default="true" />

It is not straight forward to pass commandline arguments from a program. Or if there is, I haven't found documentation for the python roslaunch module.
content.html:
I want to automate the launching and store the logs in a database. Are teams allowed to change the defaults in the launch file?

ie. <arg name="extra_gazebo_args" default=""/> <arg name="init" default="false" />
to <arg name="extra_gazebo_args" default="-r"/> <arg name="init" default="true" />

It is not straight forward to pass commandline arguments from a program. Or if there is, I haven't found documentation for the python roslaunch module.

content.raw:
When using ihmc's hand trajectory controller there seems to be two unreferenced frames that are being used to reference with the world frame that does not exist. One for the left hand and one for the right. As I understand sending commands to this topic controls the position and orientation of these unnamed/unreferenced frames. The unknown(rightHand) frame is approximately +0.1m in the x axis and -0.025 in the y axis of the (rightPalm) frame and the unknown(leftHand) is +0.1m in the x axis and -0.025 in the y axis of the (leftPalm). 
With my findings I conclude that the HandTrajectory controllers have frames that aren't accessible. I tried to use the index finger for buffer but I couldn't access the fingers either as I believe they're still in progress. 
Is there any suggestion you can give me or will I just have to work off the right and left Palm frames and insert the offsets manually?
Looking further into these frames, they seem to be the point of grasping for the robot. Were these going to be added later?

One for the left hand and one for the right. As I understand sending commands to this topic controls the position and orientation of these unnamed/unreferenced frames. The unknown(rightHand) frame is approximately +0.1m in the x axis and -0.025 in the y axis of the (rightPalm) frame and the unknown(leftHand) is +0.1m in the x axis and -0.025 in the y axis of the (leftPalm). With my findings I conclude that the HandTrajectory controllers have frames that aren't accessible. I tried to use the index finger for buffer but I couldn't access the fingers either as I believe they're still in progress. Is there any suggestion you can give me or will I just have to work off the right and left Palm frames and insert the offsets manually? Looking further into these frames, they seem to be the point of grasping for the robot. Were these going to be added later?

content.raw:
The button is still reversed on my system. There is a comment on the original issue #27 that another is seeing the same problem. Since #27 is marked resolved I'm creating this issue to bring it to the forefront. 

I can actually see that pressing the button does not work but the occasional time when the hand drags on the side of the button there is movement and the door opens. 

<<I removed the package, did an update srcsim and reinstalled using apt-get. I see the same results. >>

Ignore the section in <<>>. I don't see an upgrade of the srcsim package in my install history and looking at commits indicates the button change could not have been in a released package as it was just a couple days ago. 

The libQual*Plugin.so files are dated 10/27/2016 after the reinstall. The package version is 0.1.0-7~Trusty. 

An issue shouldn't be marked as resolved until it is released to the wild. 

When are we going to see this fix? It's a little over a month to the deadline and this is a critical function.
content.html:
The button is still reversed on my system. There is a comment on the original issue #27 that another is seeing the same problem. Since #27 is marked resolved I'm creating this issue to bring it to the forefront.

I can actually see that pressing the button does not work but the occasional time when the hand drags on the side of the button there is movement and the door opens.

<<I removed the package, did an update srcsim and reinstalled using apt-get. I see the same results. >>

Ignore the section in <<>>. I don't see an upgrade of the srcsim package in my install history and looking at commits indicates the button change could not have been in a released package as it was just a couple days ago.

The libQual*Plugin.so files are dated 10/27/2016 after the reinstall. The package version is 0.1.0-7~Trusty.

An issue shouldn't be marked as resolved until it is released to the wild.

When are we going to see this fix? It's a little over a month to the deadline and this is a critical function.

content.raw:
Hello,

Quick question, how much can our qualifying solutions interact with gazebo itself? Gazebo publishes a number of topics that could be quite useful in the solutions, however that seems counter to the spirit of the competition and would clearly not be valid on the real robot.

However if use of those gazebo topics is perfectly valid then it is likely that all the qualifying teams are going to be using them and anyone who tries to do without those topics will be left behind.

If possible I would like some clarity on this question.

Thanks,

-aric

values.title: rospy init_node does work second time through

content.raw:
I "rospy.signal _shutdown()", cleanup(), etc. While the node disappears from the rosnode list list, it is still around and a second rospy.init_node call fails.

I am trying to automate my simulations and this is a magor bug I assume in ROS.  If I try running roscore first and just one rospy.node_init)(), I get a flood of TF_OLD_DATA warnings at subsequent roslaunches as some internal data has the last simulations timing data.

Seems there should be a way to run multiple simulations sequentially.
content.html:
I "rospy.signal _shutdown()", cleanup(), etc. While the node disappears from the rosnode list list, it is still around and a second rospy.init_node call fails.

I am trying to automate my simulations and this is a magor bug I assume in ROS. If I try running roscore first and just one rospy.node_init)(), I get a flood of TF_OLD_DATA warnings at subsequent roslaunches as some internal data has the last simulations timing data.

Seems there should be a way to run multiple simulations sequentially.

values.title: Refinement of collision elements for valkyrie_sim_gazebo_sync

content.raw: The URDF files for the valkyrie model used in the simulation seem to have irrational collision elements, which causes systems that account for the collision, such as MoveIt!, to require a significant amount of modification to accommodate for the collisions. Such examples include collision between the shoulder and pelvis links, even though they are realistically impossible to collide.
content.html: The URDF files for the valkyrie model used in the simulation seem to have irrational collision elements, which causes systems that account for the collision, such as MoveIt!, to require a significant amount of modification to accommodate for the collisions. Such examples include collision between the shoulder and pelvis links, even though they are realistically impossible to collide.

values.title: running srcsim on an amazon cloud instance

content.raw:
Seems like I'm not the only one having trouble with Ubuntu 14 related issues.  My solution was to hack together a version of this running on an amazon e2c p2.xlarge server (it has a GPU so hopefully GPU_RAY will work).  

I wrote a guide: http://nonholonomy.com/portfolio/?id=1 on how I did it, but if anyone is interested I might have time to package the ebs volume into something share-able.

Note: I just put this together and some things still don't work (e.g. gui in remote desktop), but with a quick tweak to the launch files (just to turn off the gui) you can connect to the server via the gazebo webgl client.

If anyone is interested, feel free to email me (avinash@nonholonomy.com).  I figure being able to spin up a few extra simulation machines could be kinda helpful right now :p
content.html:
Seems like I'm not the only one having trouble with Ubuntu 14 related issues. My solution was to hack together a version of this running on an amazon e2c p2.xlarge server (it has a GPU so hopefully GPU_RAY will work).

I wrote a guide: http://nonholonomy.com/portfolio/?id=1 on how I did it, but if anyone is interested I might have time to package the ebs volume into something share-able.

Note: I just put this together and some things still don't work (e.g. gui in remote desktop), but with a quick tweak to the launch files (just to turn off the gui) you can connect to the server via the gazebo webgl client.

If anyone is interested, feel free to email me (avinash@nonholonomy.com). I figure being able to spin up a few extra simulation machines could be kinda helpful right now :p

values.title: will the NeckTrajectory function be fixed?

content.raw:
Are the NeckTrajectory messages working?

If the are can you post or direct us to an example script?

If the aren't working, will you release a version of the software with the neck trajectory working soon?

here's what I am using:

NECK1 = [0.3, 0.5, -0.5]

def sendNeckTrajectory():
    msg = NeckTrajectoryRosMessage()
    msg = appendTrajectoryPoint(msg, 1.0, NECK1)
    msg.unique_id = time.time()
    rospy.loginfo('publishing neck trajectory')
    neckTrajectoryPublisher.publish(msg)

content.raw:
I just did a fresh install of SRCSIM on a new PC last night.  I believe it was just after a release that allowed the neck and arms to be controllable. Now when I launch Qual2, the head shakes back and forth randomly and never stops.  I even tried the new keyboard_teleop.py script to see if I could regain control of the neck that way, but no luck.  When I would adjust the positon of the neck, it would jump to that position and then start rotating again, sometimes the jump would be harsh enough to make Val fall over.  

After a few hours of investigating, I think the root of the cause is an error in the head IMU sensor.  below is some output I get when Q2 is starting up.  

****[ INFO] [1484415336.496335112, 6.787000000]: SharedMemoryInterfacePlugin: Loading
2017-01-14 12:35:36 localhost ncl_cpp: [WARN] 

[gov.nasa.SharedMemorySimInterfacePlugin.findUrdfSensors] Possibly missing an api or node tag from one or more imu sensors
2017-01-14 12:35:36 localhost ncl_cpp: [WARN] 

[gov.nasa.SharedMemorySimInterfacePlugin.findUrdfSensors] Imu sensor head_imu_sensor doesn't have <imuTransform> tag. It is likely that the data you receive from this sensor will be incorrect.

[ INFO] [1484415336.530239249, 6.787000000]: SharedMemorySimInterfacePlugin: Loading complete!****

I am working on trying to find a solution to this issue, but so far am not having any luck.  The head shaking makes it so Val can hardly walk, so I can't just ignore it.  I have attached my the entire output I get when starting up Q2.
content.html:
I just did a fresh install of SRCSIM on a new PC last night. I believe it was just after a release that allowed the neck and arms to be controllable. Now when I launch Qual2, the head shakes back and forth randomly and never stops. I even tried the new keyboard_teleop.py script to see if I could regain control of the neck that way, but no luck. When I would adjust the positon of the neck, it would jump to that position and then start rotating again, sometimes the jump would be harsh enough to make Val fall over.

After a few hours of investigating, I think the root of the cause is an error in the head IMU sensor. below is some output I get when Q2 is starting up.

****[ INFO] [1484415336.496335112, 6.787000000]: SharedMemoryInterfacePlugin: Loading 2017-01-14 12:35:36 localhost ncl_cpp: [WARN]

content.raw:
There are some issues being discussed on the forum that have no clear answer, or if it has, it is conflicting with what has been said for the last 3 months and affects directly the results of the competition.

Regarding qualification 1, [here the PHD stated](https://ninesights.ninesigma.com/web/space-robotics-challenge/forum/-/message_boards/message/16755734#_19_message_16776326)  it is said that qualification 1 is expected to be done with stereo instead of LIDAR.
But in the [qualification 1 instructions](#!/osrf/srcsim/wiki/qual_task1) is it said that LIDAR can be used to obtain the position of the buttons.

Regarding qualification 1 & 2, in the forums [the PHD has stated ](https://ninesights.ninesigma.com/web/space-robotics-challenge/forum/-/message_boards/message/16766481#_19_message_16770738) that the final score is also dependent on subjective elements. 

So I would like someone to provide a final answer to these questions.

1. What is the minimum required precision for qual1?

2. Is LIDAR allowed in the qual1?

3. If not, how is it going to be enforced? If our team sends results obtained from pure stereo vision, how are we sure that someone who submitted with LIDAR because he hasn't read this issue or that particular forum gets a better score? Is this team who didn't check this issue or forum post disqualified?

4. What are the subjective elements? What criteria should we use to submit our results to not get penalized or to get a subjective bonus score? 

5. Will the results of the 20 winner teams be made public? Not necessarily the logs, but the results of the scoring scripts (time & precision for qual 1, and time for qual 2)
content.html:
There are some issues being discussed on the forum that have no clear answer, or if it has, it is conflicting with what has been said for the last 3 months and affects directly the results of the competition.

Regarding qualification 1, here the PHD stated it is said that qualification 1 is expected to be done with stereo instead of LIDAR. But in the qualification 1 instructions is it said that LIDAR can be used to obtain the position of the buttons.

Regarding qualification 1 & 2, in the forums the PHD has stated that the final score is also dependent on subjective elements.

So I would like someone to provide a final answer to these questions.

  1. What is the minimum required precision for qual1?

  2. Is LIDAR allowed in the qual1?

  3. If not, how is it going to be enforced? If our team sends results obtained from pure stereo vision, how are we sure that someone who submitted with LIDAR because he hasn't read this issue or that particular forum gets a better score? Is this team who didn't check this issue or forum post disqualified?

  4. What are the subjective elements? What criteria should we use to submit our results to not get penalized or to get a subjective bonus score?

  5. Will the results of the 20 winner teams be made public? Not necessarily the logs, but the results of the scoring scripts (time & precision for qual 1, and time for qual 2)

values.title: Should we filter the qual 2 log for submission or not?

content.raw:
The ['FILE NAMING CONVENTION' post on the ninesigma forums](https://ninesights.ninesigma.com/web/space-robotics-challenge/forum/-/message_boards/message/16776650) indicates that only the Task 1 log should be compressed.   The instructions in the srcsim bitbucket wiki include this filtering step for processing task 2 logs for submission:
```bash
gz log -e -f state.log --filter *.pose/*.pose -z 60 > qual_2.log
```
However, the instructions for the scoring script ask that we process the log like so:
```bash
gz log -e -f state.log > qual_2.log
``` 
with the explanation

>The default log files are compressed to reduce its size but the scoring scripts need uncompressed log files

Which way should we be processing task 2 logs for submission?  

Thanks!
content.html:
The 'FILE NAMING CONVENTION' post on the ninesigma forums indicates that only the Task 1 log should be compressed. The instructions in the srcsim bitbucket wiki include this filtering step for processing task 2 logs for submission:

gz log -e -f state.log --filter *.pose/*.pose -z 60 > qual_2.log

However, the instructions for the scoring script ask that we process the log like so:

gz log -e -f state.log > qual_2.log

with the explanation

The default log files are compressed to reduce its size but the scoring scripts need uncompressed log files

Which way should we be processing task 2 logs for submission?

Thanks!

values.title: Be explicit about Task 1 CP 2 being two separate checkpoints

content.raw:
Some concerns [arose](#!/osrf/srcsim/pull-requests/30/finals-plugin/diff#comment-31491912) about merging task 1's satellite checkpoints into a single checkpoint. 

On the rules, the task has 4 checkpoints, where checkpoints 2 and 3 can be performed in any order. In the implementation, there are 3 checkpoints, and checkpoint 2 corresponds to checkpoints 2 and 3 from the rules. That single checkpoint will be scored as if it were 2 checkpoints which can be performed in any order.

As far as I can tell, from the user's point of view, the differences are:

* If a user wants to skip one of the 2 merged checkpoints, they have to solve one of them first, and then skip the remaining one.

* If a user wants to skip both checkpoints and go straight to the finish box, they will skip to "checkpoint 3" instead of "checkpoint 4"

* At the moment, there is no feedback through ROS messages for users about the time when the separate checkpoints were individually achieved, although it is possible to infer from the time when `yaw_completed`  or `pitch_completed` become true.

Am I missing anything?
content.html:
Some concerns arose about merging task 1's satellite checkpoints into a single checkpoint.

On the rules, the task has 4 checkpoints, where checkpoints 2 and 3 can be performed in any order. In the implementation, there are 3 checkpoints, and checkpoint 2 corresponds to checkpoints 2 and 3 from the rules. That single checkpoint will be scored as if it were 2 checkpoints which can be performed in any order.

As far as I can tell, from the user's point of view, the differences are:

  • If a user wants to skip one of the 2 merged checkpoints, they have to solve one of them first, and then skip the remaining one.

  • If a user wants to skip both checkpoints and go straight to the finish box, they will skip to "checkpoint 3" instead of "checkpoint 4"

  • At the moment, there is no feedback through ROS messages for users about the time when the separate checkpoints were individually achieved, although it is possible to infer from the time when yaw_completed or pitch_completed become true.

Am I missing anything?

values.title: rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 1 3 does not move to finish

content.raw:
Ran the command:

```
#!c++

roslaunch srcsim unique_task1.launch init:="true"

```

Then skipped to checkpoint 3 with the command and results:

```
#!c++
rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 1 3


Msg] Task [1] - Checkpoint [1] - Skipped (30 767000000)

[Msg] Task [1] - Checkpoint [3] - Started (30 767000000)
[Msg] Started box contains plugin [task1/checkpoint3]
```

R5 jumped to in front of the satellite dish wheels. Expected it to go to finish box.

values.title: Head trajectory pitch > 0.47 hangs head / neck response

content.raw:
Using the python keyboard script if the head pitches to 0.5 it will tip forward beyond that value and become unresponsive. 

With my C++ code if the head pitches past 0.47 the head pitches beyond the limit and becomes unresponsive. This code is using the head-trajectory message.
content.html:
Using the python keyboard script if the head pitches to 0.5 it will tip forward beyond that value and become unresponsive.

With my C++ code if the head pitches past 0.47 the head pitches beyond the limit and becomes unresponsive. This code is using the head-trajectory message.

values.title: Val can't stand up after update

content.raw:
After updating, it looks like the controller does start and Val's joints go to the home position, but she doesn't stay up.  I did a full reinstall but get the same behavior.  I think I've tried all the solutions posted in the other issue threads.  

[Video of Val falling](https://youtu.be/y07PRmKK1WI)

[Snippet of the output](https://bitbucket.org/snippets/jedediyah/7enbM)

This was happening before but I could disable networking during launch and for some reason that avoided the problem.  However, if I disable networking now I get the error similar to Issue #92  

```
#!bash

FAILURE: Build failed with an exception.

* What went wrong:
Execution failed for task ':runJavaDelegate'.
> Could not resolve all dependencies for configuration ':ros'.
   > Could not determine artifacts for xml-apis:xml-apis:2.0.2
      > Could not get resource 'https://jcenter.bintray.com/xml-apis/xml-apis/2.0.2/xml-apis-2.0.2.jar'.
         > Could not HEAD 'https://jcenter.bintray.com/xml-apis/xml-apis/2.0.2/xml-apis-2.0.2.jar'.
            > jcenter.bintray.com
```
I did the Pre-build ihmc_ros_java_adapter step and it completes in about 4 seconds (it used to take 8 minutes).  So I tried the steps in Issue #86 but with no luck.
